data.title: Schenectady native Zac Strachan’s unorthodox bowling style works for him — In The Pocket
data.meta_description: IN THE POCKET – Zac Strachan admits to utilizing an unorthodox bowling style, but the powerful Schenectady native knocks down… Read more »
data.meta_site_name: The Daily Gazette Family of Newspapers
data.text:
The 30-year-old Mohawk Honda employee showed off his magic touch last Sunday morning in the four-game Jack Scaccia NFL league, when he recorded 30 strikes in his last 36 frames. Strachan opened up with a 215 game, but then he really found the line over his next three games, shooting games of 245, 279 and 299 for an 823.

“I’ve got an unconventional style,” Strachan explained. “A lot of people poke fun at me. I never have my left hand touch the ball at all, and I keep everything very simple. But then I kind of fall off a little bit at the end. But it gets the job done, for sure.”

Strachan is currently averaging 217 in both the Jack Scaccia NFL and the Friday night Galaxy league, both at Boulevard Bowl. His highest career average was a 222 a couple of years ago while competing in the Frank DePalma Boulevard Classic league. Strachan owns two sanctioned perfect games and three 800 triples.

“He’s a kid that throws hard with a lot of speed. He cranks the ball pretty good, and he’s a one-hander. He’s a darn good bowler,” said good friend Doug Hopkins, who also bowls in the Galaxy league.

Strachan learned the game from Schenectady USBC Hall of Famer and current Schenectady High School girls’ coach Sharon Sager.

“Sharon Sager was a huge part of my bowling career,” Strachan said. “She got me started and had me continue through no matter how much I struggled early. Her junior bowling program was very important to me.”

“He does have a unique style,” Sager said. “We did try to change it, but if it works, then you shouldn’t try to change it. He was always very interested in bowling and trying to get better. He never gave up as a junior bowler. When he bowled badly, then he just kept going and tried to do better. He wasn’t a very animated bowler, but he was very competitive. He’s a great team player, as well. I am very proud of the bowler that he has become and proud of the person he is.”

After graduating from Schenectady High School, Strachan studied at SUNY Schenectady for a year before moving to Long Island. He said he bowled at Farmingdale Lanes for the 2013 season before moving back to the Capital Region.

Strachan said he’s competed in numerous area leagues, including the City League at Towne Bowling Academy, the NFL Summer league at Boulevard Bowl, the City Catholic league at Boulevard Bowl and the Mt. Carmel league before he joined the Galaxy league a couple of years ago.

“My biggest triple was an 835 in the Galaxy league,” Strachan said. “I shot a 279, 299 and 257. But I would say one of my best accomplishments on the lanes was winning a big team tournament at Town ’N Country Lanes with my good friend Ryan Karabin and Courtney LeMora. I used to work at Boulevard Bowl with Ryan.”

Strachan also finished in the top five of a weekly tournament in the now-defunct Northeast Bowling Proprietors of New York Huck Finn Capital Region Bowling Show.

“What I really love about bowling is the social aspect,” Strachan said. “I love to hang out with a couple of my friends and bowl. It’s even been a lot of fun helping to get my in-laws back into the game. It’s just a really good time to get a bunch of people out there on the lanes together.”

Strachan said he enjoyed the only time he participated in the USBC National Tournament when it was held in Syracuse, and he wants to bowl more competitive events.

“My career goals are to get into more tournaments. I want to get out there to the nationals once again and put myself into more competitive situations with tougher shots,” he said.

My buddies and I had the opportunity to bowl on the same pair of lanes with Strachan and his friends during a charity event a couple of years ago, and it was a blast as the Strachan group was not only very talented and competitive, but also extremely good sports.

STRONG FIELD FOR REGIONAL

Many of the Capital Region’s top bowlers, as well as a strong contingent of regional pros, will square off at the PBA Kingpin’s Family Fun Center RPI Open Saturday and Sunday. Local standouts include Zachary Bogholtz (Nassau), Alexander Bonesteel (Latham), Brandon Boyer (Hudson Falls), Hunter Chandler (Porter Corners), Frank Cataldo (Fort Edward), Matt Fazzone (Rotterdam), Macallan Gagne (Saratoga Springs), Angelo Galofaro (Schenectady), Joshua Gitto (Gansevoort), Kevin Goodell Jr. (Queensbury), James Gregware Jr. (Rensselaer), Brett Groff (Schenectady), Warren Guernsey (Watervliet), Former PBA50 Player ofthe Year Brian LeClair (Delmar), R.J. Martinez (Ballston Spa), Billy McGaffin Jr. (Amsterdam), Nick Miseno (Ballston Spa), Corey Miglucci (Selkirk),, Thomas Reed (Mechanicville), Anthony Scaccia (Voorheesville), Robert Skivington (Warrensburg), Eric Stangle (Ballston Spa), and Roy Vanderbogart (Queensbury).

Current PBA50 standout Ryan Shafer heads a field of regional pros that includes former Donato Scratch Singles champions Alex Cavagnaro and Phil Drumm, John Furey, Ryan Galli, Zach Gentile, Anthony Neuer, Anthony Pepe and Jonathan Wilbur.

STRIKES & SPARES

Town ’N Country’s Fall Semi-Classic will be held Oct. 4 (9 p.m.), Oct. 7 (10 a.m. and 1 p.m. and Oct. 8 (10 a.m. and 1 p.m.). Handicap is 90% of 215. There will be an optional doubles event. Entry fee is $50. Cash ratio will be 1 in 6 for singles and 1 in 8 for doubles. Top prize for singles is $1,000. Contact Anthony Scaccia (518-881-5054) for more information.

Congratulations to Lindsey McPhail, who rolled a pair of perfect games this week, including one during an 836 triple. She has 15 perfect games.

Saturday’s Baker Doubles Tournament at Perry Lanes has been rescheduled.

Kingpin’s Alley Latham hosts the 3-6-9 BVL (Bowling to Veterans Link) Oct. 15. The BVL provides recreation and entertainment to veterans in VA medical centers. The event is put on by the Albany USBC. Entry fee is $15, but walk-ins will be accepted at $20. There will be two squads, 10:30 a.m. and 1 p.m. All bowlers will roll three games with a free strike in the third, sixth and ninth frames. The divisions will be Class AA (210 average and above), Class A (190-209), Class B (170-189), Class C (150-169), Class D (130-149) and Class E (129 and under). Bowlers will use their highest average from last season. Make checks out to Albany USBC Association. For more information, contact Albany USBC manager Bob Napier a 518-874-4544.

The Capital District Youth Scholarship Tour begins its 14th season next Saturday (Sept. 30) at Del Lanes. At least $500 will be added to the scholarship fund. Entry fee remains at $50 ($40 for the U12 division), and there will be optional Junior Gold qualifying at all tournaments. For more information, visit www.cdystbowling.com.

The 45th annual NYS Open Senior Championships are set for Oct. 14-15 at Sportsman’s Bowl. Senior bowlers age 50 and older can compete in doubles, singles and six-game combined events in the Class E (50-54), Class D (55-59), Class C (60-64), Class B (65-69), Class A (70-74) and Super Senior (75 and up) age divisions. There will be three squads each day (10 a.m., 1 p.m. and 4 p.m.). Entry fee is $70 per doubles team, $35 for singles and an added $10 for six-game combined. Contact NYS USBC Association Manager Angelo Corradino (845-363-1374) or bowlnysubc@gmail.com for more information.

The Daily Gazette league, which bowls Tuesdays at noon at Sportsman’s Bowl, has openings for at least four bowlers for the 2023-24 season. It’s a 10-team mixed league with a 100% handicap. Dues are $17 a week. Contact Sportsman’s Bowl or secretary Marty Browne for more information.

Uncle Sam Lanes will host the 27th annual 800 Club Tournament Oct. 21. There will be one squad at 12:30 p.m. Competitors must have rolled a scratch 800 triple in a Troy Bowling Association sanctioned league or tournament, and all bowlers must be USBC certified. Entry fee is $45. The top 10 bowlers after qualifying will roll one more game to determine the top five for the stepladder finals.

Town ‘N Country Lanes hosts the opening event of the Amateur League Bowlers Association of New York series for bowlers with averages of 215 and lower. It will be a doubles tournament on Oct. 22.Uncle Sam Lanes in Troy hosts the first singles tournament Nov. 19, followed by another singles event Dec. 10 at Sportsman’s Bowl, which also hosts the second doubles tournament of the season on Jan. 7. In February, there will be two special tournaments for members with established averages in A.L.B.A.N.Y. events. Uncle Sam Lanes entertains another singles event March 17, followed by the “Main Event” season-ending championship April 28 at Kingpin’s Alley Latham. All tournaments begin at 9:30 a.m. Contact Burton (518-209-4748) for more information.

Kingpin’s Alley Family Fun Center is the site for the TNBA Albany Senate Trio Tournament Oct. 19. All bowlers must be certified by both the TNBA and the USBC. There will be three squads: 10 a.m., 1 p.m. and 4 p.m. Entry fee is $90 per team, plus optional handicap singles and/or scratch singles at $10 each. Handicap will be based on 90% of a 690 team average, and singles event handicap will be based on 90% of 230. For more information, contact Robert Danzy (518-507-2218).

Also at Kingpin’s Alley Family Fun Center is the Scratch Baker Doubles Tournament Oct. 15 with first place guaranteed at $2,000. Entry fee is $200 per team. Call 518-793-9606 for more information.

MAJOR BOWLING

Tom Siatkowski ripped a pair of 257 games during a 746, Austin Van Buren hammered a 258-737 and Billy McGaffin Jr. rolled a 279-729 to pace the Sportsman’s Majors Monday night at Sportsman’s Bowl.

Jeff Whitehouse recorded a perfect game during an 803 triple, Andrew Hall shot a 279-778, Justin Barcomb also had a 300 game (his 93rd career perfect game) during his 771 and Jessica Aiezza tossed a 268-760 for the top performances in the Jamie Mazuryk Homes Team City League Monday night at Towne Bowling Academy.

B.J. Smith Jr. connected for a 269-1,015 four-game series, Tony Bianchi ripped a 268-990, Derek Foti shot a 279-945, Mike Scaccia pounded a 268-941, John Mecca delivered a 279-929 and Mark Hansen registered a 252-921 in the Frank DePalma Boulevard Classic at Boulevard Bowl.

McGaffin rolled a perfect game during a 1,084 four-game series, Matt Fazzone shot a 268-962, John Askew and Mike Kamm each fired a 957 and Natasha Fazzone ripped a 262-939 to lead the Towne Mixed Doubles Wednesday night at Towne Bowling Academy.

Chamar Goodwin cranked out a 279-793, Joe DiBiase ripped a 279-772 and Mike Voss slammed a 268-762 in the Capital District All Star league Thursday night at Sportsman’s Bowl.
